comments.text:
Gee, I thought conservatives were against people using welfare?  You do 
realize Medicaid is a government program, right?  Your other choice would 
have been the people who want to get rid of Medicaid completely (i.e., the 
Republicans.)

You should be aware that the Affordable Care Act was originally developed 
by the Heritage Foundation, a super conservative think tank, and 
representatives of the health insurance industry.  It's a conservative, 
Republican plan.  It was only adopted by Obama because he thought the 
Republicans would go for their own plan; but they used it to attack him any 
way.  The liberal plan would have been to go for a single payer system, 
such as a "Medicare for All" type of plan (similar to what Canada has; all 
primary health insurance would be handled through one government 
organization while all health care providers would remain private, for 
profit entities.  It would mean that a person who needs to see a specialist 
at the other end of the US would have full coverage to do so and would not 
be limited to the doctors in their plan.  Not to mention is would cost a 
lot less money since there would be so much less overhead being paid for; 
for the insurance companies, hiring armies of people to deny claims costs a 
lot!  And under such a plan, private insurance companies would still be 
allowed to sell supplementary insurance plans to those who want it.)

Are you even sure that your son losing his Medicaid has anything to do with 
the ACA and if it does, that it's the federal government's fault?  
Considering how many state governors are refusing to implement the ACA and 
the Medicaid expansion, it could very well be that it's your state 
government that's to blame. 

Rich liberal?  Gee, haven't conservatives been saying that liberals are the 
47% of the population that live off the government teat and only vote 
democrat to get free stuff (even though liberals use less welfare?)  Why 
can't conservatives get their lies straight?

comments.text:
Usually I don't comment on YouTube videos but I'm just curious about 
something without intending to attack anyone on their views. I live in 
Holland (born and raised), at the moment the average monthly fee for a 
decent health insurance is about 120 Euro a month and our default 
detuctable rate is 350 Euro. Which mean we pay about 1800 Euro's a year to 
able to have most things covered. I have a friend living in the US that has 
a low paying full time job. He told me he has to be pay around 400 dollars 
a month and his detuctable is 3000 dollar which makes 7800 dollars a year 
before he actually receives something from his insurance. Here in Holland 
prior to 2000 people paid around 20 Euro's (back then in a different 
currency) and everyone was insured by default and you'd only have to 
starting paying when you turned 18. People here in Holland complain about 
the new health care systems that keeps getting more expensive every year, 
but if you look at the system you guys have in the US we should be happy 
with it. In countries like France, Britain and Canada people don't pay 
anything outside their taxes and are completely insured with never any 
questions asked at hospitals, doctor's offices etc. Don't US citizens find 
it odd that in a such a modern and industrialized nation people have to pay 
such large fees to be able to get medical health service? Holland is just a 
small country so I understand the number of citizens doesn't come close to 
comparison to the US which I think makes these things more complicated but 
even in large countries like France they do not seem to have these 
problems. I just wonder if US citizens are aware of this and how you feel 
about it.﻿

comments.text:
Here is the story of a different Julie
The first of many deaths to come from Obamacare. The Sister of Doug Gramm, 
wife and mother of four, Julie and her family were covered by a medical 
plan they liked.  Her family private health care policy was cancelled 
because of the Affordable Care Act. So she struggled through the expensive, 
time consuming and incompetently designed Obamacare website to find a new 
policy. While they waited for their new Obama-approved healthcare plan to 
start she fell ill. She couldn’t eat solid food. She should have gone to a 
doctor sooner but with the Obama economy she wanted to wait until her new 
coverage would kick in, February 2, to avoid a medical expense on a 
strained house-hold budget.  When Julie finally got to the doctor they 
found a badly blocked gall bladder that had become highly infected. Her 
body went into septic shock just two days before her Obamacare policy would 
have kicked in. Her kidneys shut down. She went to the emergency room 
where, after heroic efforts, a marvelous medical team managed to stabilize 
her condition. Early the next day her heart stopped beating around 4:00 
a.m. February 1st.﻿

comments.text:
As a type 1 diabetic in Denmark, I have the legal right to 4 specialist 
visits at a hospital a year when everything is fine and my blood sugar is 
well regulated, just to get blood tests done and to test my kidney 
function. I get more visits if I need them, or I can contact a diabetic 
nurse "out of season" for minor problems. I get a comprehensive eye test 
done each year to make sure I don't go blind. I can go to a dietician if I 
need help with my food. I get supplies for my insulin pump sent to my door 
every 3 months, without me having to do anything. If I need blood glucose 
testing equipment, I can just go online and order it, and it will be at my 
door 1 - 3 days later.
I can do all of this without ever having to pay out of pocket. I love it! :)

However, I do have to pay for my insulin - a whopping maximum of $500 a 
year! :P On top of that I actually have to go to a pharmacy to get it! The 
nerve! Lol

Also, to make things worse, I can't apply for private health insurance, 
because of a pre-existing condition... :P Oh well. :D﻿

"Long-term care and nursing care are not covered. Since Boonstra’s leukemia 
diagnosis five years ago, she spent two-and-a-half years bed-ridden. If 
that happens again, she’s got a big problem.

The statement of benefits says glaucoma is not covered. Leukemia is a 
disease that ravages every part of the body, so lack of coverage for 
glaucoma (or even dental care, which is also highly relevant for a leukemia 
patient and is also not covered) is a very serious issue.

Boonstra is on five different medications to help deal with her leukemia. 
The Blue Cross PR spokesman claimed that they are all covered. But when 
Boonstra went to fill her prescription for Loratadine — a 
prescription-level equivalent of Claritin that she uses to control 
congestion brought on by chemotherapy — she was told that Loratadine is not 
covered. She has not yet attempted to restock any of her other meds but she 
is already having to come with strategies to deal with that problem.

The $5,100 cap on Boonstra’s out-of-pocket spending is for in-network care 
only. If she has to go out of network, she could spend an additional 
$10,200. The “fact checkers” treat this as impossible because Boonstra’s 
doctor is in network, but anyone who has ever dealt with cancer would know 
there is no way of predicting where you will have to go to find care.

When Boonstra was first diagnosed, she had to go through a painstaking 
process to get approval for her chemotherapy drugs to be covered. When she 
finally found insurance she liked, she had no problem with the chemo drugs. 
She now says that process is starting all over again.

Boonstra has already had to cut back on her bone marrow biopsies, which she 
was having on a regular schedule she had worked out with her doctor, 
because she doesn’t have clarification on whether these will be covered."

comments.text:
+amy glass "Most people are one diagnosis or emergency room treatment away 
from bankruptcy or homelessness."

First of all, no most people are NOT one medical problem away from 
bankruptcy and homelessness. If that were the case, then no amount of 
healthy young adults could have EVER been able to offset the costs of the 
Affordable Healthcare Act. Second of all, people racking up 10,000+ dollars 
a year because of high deductibles isn't going to help their impending 
bankruptcy and homelessness. 

"AMY GLASS SAID: Lack of health insurance is a major issue in this country 
and that is a shame for such a rich and prosperous country like the U.S."

I never said otherwise. In fact this a fallacy because it has nothing to do 
with "my" argument. My statement never denied the fact that access to 
affordable healthcare is a problem in this country. Rather my point was 
that 6,000 dollar deductibles does not give the AVERAGE person access to 
affordable healthcare. Why? Because the average person does not have 
medical issues that requires 6,000 dollars to fix. I have a chronic 
illness, and I STILL don't use anywhere near 6,000 dollars a year for 
medical care. 

So when I, as a person who makes 14k a year, can only obtain "cheap" 
medical insurance with a 4,000-6,000 dollar deductible, basically all I'm 
doing is paying for an insurance that I can never benefit from (unless I 
develop cancer or contract AIDS, etc). So I'll be paying for insurance, but 
I won't actually receive assistance for my medical treatments because they 
equal well-below 6,000 dollars a year, but they're still above $1,000.


"AMY GLASS SAID: Americans need to wake up and stop being scared of code 
words like "socialism" being spewed by the rightwing who benefit from and 
enjoy socialism themselves without acknowledging it. Wall 
Street/corporations enjoys socialism in the form of tax breaks and bailouts 
so why shouldn't regular folks. All other industrialized nations have 
universal health coverage. With a lot of people- some healthier than 
others- in an insurance pool, prices come down for everybody"

Again, this has nothing to do with my contentions. In fact I even agree 
with you. Words like communism and socialism are largely misunderstood 
because the population is ignorant of political history. These words do not 
scare me, as I am not under the thrall of either the Republicans or the 
Democrats. As far as I'm concerned they're both one in the same, and they 
both want to ensure Dema-Republican hegemony of American politics (no 
matter the costs).

Universal healthcare with the public option of buying private insurance 
would help a lot of people get the care that they need; allow people the 
chance to buy insurance so that they can get faster service time at smaller 
clinics; and my personal favorite, dramatically decrease the unlimited 
power of the corrupt Insurance corporations. 

This is all great, but it still has nothing to do with my original point. 
If I'm not actually being helped by insurance in any way, then I will NOT 
pay for it. I'm not a perfectly healthy young adult. I have chronic 
illnesses that I cannot afford to pay out of pocket. Guess what else I 
can't afford to pay out of pocket? 6,000 dollars in deductibles...
comments.author: biggtk

comments.text:
+biggtk Most people are one diagnosis or emergency room treatment away from 
bankruptcy or homelessness. Lack of health insurance is a major issue in 
this country and that is a shame for such a rich and prosperous country 
like the U.S. If we had a public option as part of Obamacare, it would have 
reduced prices even further but that was not an option since republicans 
wouldn't allow it and many were suckered into believing it was gasp! 
communism! I think what they mean is socialism. As if we don't already have 
that in this country with Medicare, social security, and Medicaid. Even 
k-12 public education is socialism. Americans need to wake up and stop 
being scared of code words like "socialism" being spewed by the rightwing 
who benefit from and enjoy socialism themselves without acknowledging it. 
Wall Street/corporations enjoys socialism in the form of tax breaks and 
bailouts so why shouldn't regular folks. All other industrialized nations 
have universal health coverage. With a lot of people- some healthier than 
others- in an insurance pool, prices come down for everybody.

comments.text:

underneath the high deductibles within these health plans. It doesn't 
matter if I ended up only paying $80 for my premium (with a tax 
credit/subsidy) if my mandatory deductible is still $4-5,000/per year. 

Why? Because I (like most Americans) will never acquire 6,000 dollars in 
medical costs within a single year. Which means that most of us will never 
actually meet our deductible costs, and therefore will never be eligible to 
receive actual assistance from our insurance plan. So basically we'd be 
paying the insurance company for the "privilege" of paying our own medical 
needs completely out-of-pocket. Please explain to me how this makes sense, 
or how this sounds like a good idea for a nation that is already suffering 
financially?

comments.text:
"she pays less per month but has a higher deductible" so basically she IS 
paying more per month, out of pocket,  because as she said her out of 
pocket costs ARE higher and that apparently means she is paying less 
overall per year?  Wait wait let me see if i heard this right.  Her out of 
pocket cost is higher that she HAS to pay before her insurance covers 
anything but that's IF she can make those costs so that she can get her 
healthcare right?  Did nobody else catch that?  So with a lower deductible, 
meaning less out of pocket cost, then paying the normal insurance cost she 
is paying 13k a year minimum but paying only 12k in her maximum with this 
new plan on a higher deductible?  Wait wait wait.  This info doesn't add 
up.  I want to see the info on this.  Say she was paying 350$ a month prior 
with a 500 deductible.  That's 850 total a month.  Now with obamacare her 
insurance has gone down to 200  (i know that's bullshit. everyone who 
actually was paying before and not on medicaid got a huge increase but 
let's just go with this for arguements sake) and the deductible is now at 
1000.  Usually 500 and 1000 are the normal deductible rates for many types 
of insurance so let's just roll with it (preferably wish i had the actual 
statistics).  So let's do the math here.  350+500=850 on her former plan. 
 200+1000=1200 on her new plan.  First off, if this were the case, how the 
hell is she saving any money at all?  Normally we always need to pay a 
deductible before any insurance activates to take over the rest of the 
costs.  If this were the case with her how the hell is she saving when she 
has to pay her end of 1000 a month PLUS the 200 she pays her insurance 
company?  Furthermore if this were a normal person and the normal 
deductible were 1000 and you never had a serious illness or injury but had 
to go in for meds due to bronchitis or something then how the hell is 
insurance cheaper for you when all you're doing now is paying out of pocket 
then paying the insurance companies because you're forced to?  Again I wish 
I had the actual figures because that quote I posted makes no sense 
whatsoever.﻿
